Title: Non-hippocampal cortical projections from the entorhinal cortex in the rat and rhesus monkey
Abstract: The entorhinal cortices are known to give rise to powerful projections that terminate in the hippocampus and dentate gyrus. Collectively, these link the hippocampal formation to many parts of the cortex and to subcortical structures like the amygdala. Non-hippocampal projections from the entorhinal cortices are understood poorly. Such projections to neighboring temporal areas in the rat and rhesus monkey have been investigated using the autoradiographic and horseradish peroxidase (HRP) tracing procedures. In the rat, HRP-labeled neurons were observed in the intermediate and lateral fields of the entorhinal cortices after injections of temporal cortical areas 20, 35, 36 and 41. They were located predominantly in layers II, III and IV. In the monkey, HRP- labeled neurons were observed in the entorhinal cortices after injections of the rostral superior temporal gyrus (area TA or 22); the temporal polar cortex (area TG or 38); the inferior temporal cortex (area TE or 20); the perirhinal cortex (area 35) and the posterior parahippocampal cortices (areas TF and TH). Unlike the rat, labeled entorhinal neurons in the monkey were located in layer IV. Autoradiographic experiments in the monkey yielded complimentary results. In view of the fact that layer IV of the entorhinal cortex in both the rat and monkey receives a powerful projection from the subicular-CAl fields of the hippocampal formation, the results imply that this layer mediates an indirect non-fornical connection between the hippocampal formation and the temporal cortex.

@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Citation: "The various layers of the entorhinal cortex are named according to Lorente de Nó rather than Cajal." (p. 202)
@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Comments:
It should be noted that Lorente de Nó's (1934) area entorhinalis comprises Brodmann's (1909) area 28 and 35.
Although Kosel et al. used Lorente de Nó's lamination scheme, they adopted Brodmann's terminolgy (Area 28) for the entorhinal cortex.

@Injections.Citation: "Two monkey brains were available for study in which tritiated amino acids ([3H]lwucine and [3H]proline) had been injected directly into the entorhinal cortex after a large ventrolateral and ventromedial temporal craniotomy. One injection (Fig. 8D) involved the more caudal parts of the entorhinal cortices and labeled the medial, lateral and intermediate fields. The other was located more rostrally and involved the lateral and intermediate entorhinal fields." (p. 208)

"Two monkey brains were available for study in which tritiated amino acids ([3H]lwucine and [3H]proline) had been injected directly into the entorhinal cortex after a large ventrolateral and ventromedial temporal craniotomy. One injection (Fig. 8D) involved the more caudal parts of the entorhinal cortices and labeled the medial, lateral and intermediate fields. The other was located more rostrally and involved the lateral and intermediate entorhinal fields." (p. 208)

"The topography of the 10 HRP injections in the rhesus monkey is shown on lateral and ventral views of te hemisphere in Fig. 5. All of these injections were made in temporal cortical areas lateral or caudal to the rhinal sulcus. Case 1 was a large injection dorsal to the rostral part of the superior temporal sulcus that extended rostrally to the pole of the temporal lobe. The cortex of supratemoral plane on the lower bank of the lateral fissure was labeled heavily. The injection site, however, did not extend across the circular sulcus into the insular cortex. The injection was judged to involve Bonin and Bailey's areas TA and TG." (pp. 205-206)

"Cases 7-10 all had injections confined to the large area of temporal cortex on the lateral surface of the hemisphere ventral to the superior temporal sulcus and rostral to the inferior occipital sulcus. None of them spread medial to the sulcus temporalis medialis anterior or the occipitotemporalis sulcus. Thus, they were located in the middle temporal area and Bonin and Bailey's area TE. In the Brodmann scheme these cases would encompass area 21, whereas cases 2-4 would involve his areas 20 and 35." (p. 208)

"Cases 2-4 were injections placed in the cortex between the rhinal sulcus and the small secondary sulcus named temporalis medial anterior. These injections in the Bonin and Bailey nomenclature would all involve area TE of the inferotemporal area. However, if Brodmann's nomenclature were used, they all involved his ventral equivalent of area TE, namely, area 20, as well as his area 35 which forms the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus." (pp. 206, 208)

"Cases 2-4 were injections placed in the cortex between the rhinal sulcus and the small secondary sulcus named temporalis medial anterior. These injections in the Bonin and Bailey nomenclature would all involve area TE of the inferotemporal area. However, if Brodmann's nomenclature were used, they all involved his ventral equivalent of area TE, namely, area 20, as well as his area 35 which forms the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus." (pp. 206, 208)

"Cases 2-4 were injections placed in the cortex between the rhinal sulcus and the small secondary sulcus named temporalis medial anterior. These injections in the Bonin and Bailey nomenclature would all involve area TE of the inferotemporal area. However, if Brodmann's nomenclature were used, they all involved his ventral equivalent of area TE, namely, area 20, as well as his area 35 which forms the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus." (pp. 206, 208)

"Cases 5 and 6 were located caudal to the rhinal sulcus in the caudal part of the parahippocampal area just medial to the rostral part of the occipitotemporal sulcus (Fig. 8A). Both cases had HRP injections confined to Bonin and Bailey's area TF." (p. 208)

"Cases 5 and 6 were located caudal to the rhinal sulcus in the caudal part of the parahippocampal area just medial to the rostral part of the occipitotemporal sulcus (Fig. 8A). Both cases had HRP injections confined to Bonin and Bailey's area TF." (p. 208)

"Cases 7-10 all had injections confined to the large area of temporal cortex on the lateral surface of the hemisphere ventral to the superior temporal sulcus and rostral to the inferior occipital sulcus. None of them spread medial to the sulcus temporalis medialis anterior or the occipitotemporalis sulcus. Thus, they were located in the middle temporal area and Bonin and Bailey's area TE. In the Brodmann scheme these cases would encompass area 21, whereas cases 2-4 would involve his areas 20 and 35." (p. 208)

"Cases 7-10 all had injections confined to the large area of temporal cortex on the lateral surface of the hemisphere ventral to the superior temporal sulcus and rostral to the inferior occipital sulcus. None of them spread medial to the sulcus temporalis medialis anterior or the occipitotemporalis sulcus. Thus, they were located in the middle temporal area and Bonin and Bailey's area TE. In the Brodmann scheme these cases would encompass area 21, whereas cases 2-4 would involve his areas 20 and 35." (p. 208)

"Cases 7-10 all had injections confined to the large area of temporal cortex on the lateral surface of the hemisphere ventral to the superior temporal sulcus and rostral to the inferior occipital sulcus. None of them spread medial to the sulcus temporalis medialis anterior or the occipitotemporalis sulcus. Thus, they were located in the middle temporal area and Bonin and Bailey's area TE. In the Brodmann scheme these cases would encompass area 21, whereas cases 2-4 would involve his areas 20 and 35." (p. 208)
